bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 10, 1940

div1.p: Truby criticizes some members of the Yellow Fever Commission for seeking undue credit. He verifies that his source of information on Lazear's death was Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 10, 1940
div1.opener:
CONFIDENTIAL
September 10, 1940.
Dr. P. S. Hench,
102 - 110 Second Avenue,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have your memorandum and yesterday morning your air mail
letter arrived. It will take me several days to work up the
information you have asked for, but I will do it as expeditiously as
possible.

During August I had my article typed and a week ago sent it
on to General Kean who will go over it with General Ireland and others.
It contains information which has never been published and there is a
grave question as to whether or not it should be. You see Agramonte
was not an active member of the Board. He did independent work in
his laboratory on the Sanarelli organism and Reed did use that to
supplement the results obtained by himself and Carroll. After that,
Agramonte was fully engaged in the work of the Department Laboratory and
Reed for that reason, and possibly for others, did not assign him to
any duties with the board but intended to use him for making autopsies.
However, no deaths occurred at Camp Lazear as you know.

Agramonte did not publish anything that I know of, about his
work with the board, until after Carroll's death. Then he made the
statement on PP. 25-26 of the Senate Document (822) and later published
an article in the Scientific Monthly (1915). There are several people
still living who know (because they were there) that Agramonte deviated
widely from the truth. Now the question is, shall the facts be brought
out? My article will never be published unless and until Kean and others
can verify every controversial point.

In your article you have quoted Agramonte very freely or at
least have used many of his statements. In view of what may happen, I
suggest that you show that it (each item) was taken from one of
Agramonte's articles.

I also suggest that you read what General Wood and dear old
“Popsie” Welch said, after Reed's death, on p.20 of the Senate Document.
- 1 -
They knew the facts and they also anticipated that others would claim
much of the credit which rightly belonged to Reed.

It is only because of the urgent desire of prominent medical
men that I have worked up my story of this unfortunate mess. Agramonte
was not the only one who tried to add to their individual glory at the
expense of Reed. Carroll was a mild offender although he owed everything
to Reed and really was devoted to him. Friends and relatives of Gorgas, too,
(not Gorgas himself) made unscrupulous efforts in this direction. Of
course you know all about Finlay and what the Cubans claim for him. I
wonder whether you have ever read the Editorial in “The Military Surgeon”
for March, 1925? If not get it and I am sure you will enjoy a well written
review of the life of General Gorgas. It is a masterpiece!

I have given you the above information because I realize how
much work you have done in preparing your memorandum. It is evident that
you have become intensely interested and should know the facts. Please
remember that it is all strictly confidential. I will send General Kean
a copy for his information so he will know that I have told you this
inside “dope”.

Now to answer your questions in the air mail letter. “Do you
mean that Major Reed told you these facts himself?” Yes. Please read
carefully the typed extracts from my article near the bottom of page two
stating that “Reed was rather cautious in discussing this aspect of
Lazear's case but he did confide in Kean and me”, etc. He evidently did
discuss it with Agramonte as his daughter's story about this, while
slightly distorted, fits in very well with what I stated as “first hand”
information.

I was amused and interested in your “detective work” in Havana.
Your conclusions were right, although perhaps you did not exactly locate
Camp Lazear or the site of our yellow fever hospital. I could promptly
put my foot on both places including the spot where Dr. Lazear died,
regardless of the changes shown in your photos. The military cemetery
where Lazear was buried was a few hundred yards from the hospital, down the
old road to La Playa, I could also locate that I am sure. The bodies were
all removed to the U. S. Lazear's final resting place, according to Kelly,
p. 271, first edition, is at London Park Cemetery, Baltimore. I suggest that
the memorial to Lazear you suggest, be a monument on the site of his death.
You may keep the photostat copy of Reed's letter to me.

I do not see any possibility of getting east this year, so it
would not be practicable for me to attend the W. & J. exercises in October,
much as I would like to be present to honor Dr. Lazear's memory.

In a few days I will send you answers to the questionnaire you
sent me and return your memorandum with more comment. I realize you will
have much to do in getting ready the final draft and need a prompt answer.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Albert E. Truby - OVER -
- 2 -
As
T
P. S.
I think it would be fine if you could
manage to get General Kean to the W & J. exercises.
He is a very fine gentleman and Reed
depended more on his advice & help than
any other man. He has always fought hard
to keep the records clean and straight in
what the Reed Board did in Cuba. He was a
friend of Lazear's as you have no doubt discovered.
When Kean gets through with my article
I hope to be able to let you see it.
While your memo & mine are cover the
same things they are materially different
I discribe our life at the Columbia Bks Hospital
and the intimate associations of our staff with
the members of the board. You will be interested
in it I am sure-
For your own information I wish to add
that while Lazear & Agramonte were classmates
at their Medical School they were not friendly and
never worked together in spite of what Agramonte
said in his statement in the Senate document.
This fact is I think known by Kean. It
is strictly confidential, too, and of course I
will never state it publicly. Agramonte & I
never had any official relationship and
we were always on friendly terms- He
was a fine pathologist and probably a good
bacteriologist. I do not know what
Major Reed thought of him, but he certainly
did not use him-
A E T
